channel.title: Wireless electricity
channel.description:
I'm surprised that nobody has made a topic yet. http://www.bestbuy.com/site/Powermat+-+Home+and+Office+Charging+Mat+-+Black/9516838.p?skuId=9516838&id=1218117579348
Will it revolutionize the world? They have already made it with a 12 foot radius in a time span of 6 months.
The product I posted can simultaneously recharge up to 3 products.
DEBATE 'N BOGGLE

item.title: Wireless electricity
item.dc:creator: @eczema3 eczema3
item.description:
@eczema3 wrote:

goatee:

Every heard of an electric tooth brush? They have been wirelessly charged for years.

ownagesbot:

There are devices like mouse chargers that do this already, albeit over a smaller radius (a few mm).

I used to have a toothbrush charged wirelessly, I think. It still had to go in its own little holder thing but there was no parts touching that would have conducted electricity.

Read full topic

item.title: Wireless electricity
item.dc:creator: @sppt sppt
item.description:
@sppt wrote:

[quote=“R.I.P RSC, post:13, topic:310882”]The tesla coil is a way to achieve wireless electricity, no?

BTW, although the mat is wireless, it’s still bound to the mat. This saves the hassle of putting a cord into a device. I’d never buy such a thing, because you still need a wire. I’d rather have something you plug into a power source and then emits electricity and charges everything in a radius of 12 meters or so. Such a device will also aide in my quest for tumors![/quote]
Good thing the human body doesn’t conduct electricity!

Read full topic

item.title: Wireless electricity
item.dc:creator: @ownagesbot ownagesbot
item.description:
@ownagesbot wrote:

There are devices like mouse chargers that do this already, albeit over a smaller radius (a few mm). When I last heard about this on the news, they were claiming it had no health risks, although that claim is quite obviously biased and perhaps almost bullshit.

Read full topic

item.title: Wireless electricity
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

The tesla coil is a way to achieve wireless electricity, no?

BTW, although the mat is wireless, it’s still bound to the mat. This saves the hassle of putting a cord into a device. I’d never buy such a thing, because you still need a wire. I’d rather have something you plug into a power source and then emits electricity and charges everything in a radius of 12 meters or so. Such a device will also aide in my quest for tumors!

Read full topic

item.title: Wireless electricity
item.dc:creator: @eczema3 eczema3
item.description:
@eczema3 wrote:

[quote=“goatee, post:11, topic:310882”][quote author=yakman link=topic=407343.msg3010911#msg3010911 date=1256766210]
you’re over a century late.

en.wikipedia.org

Wireless power transfer

Wireless power transfer (WPT), wireless power transmission, wireless energy transmission, or electromagnetic power transfer is the transmission of electrical energy without wires as a physical link. In a wireless power transmission system, a transmitter device, driven by electric power from a power source, generates a time-varying electromagnetic field, which transmits power across space to a receiver device, which extracts power from the field and supplies it to an electrical load. Wireless ...

A global system for “the transmission of electrical energy without wires” dependant upon the high electrical conductivity of the earth was proposed by Nikola Tesla as early as 1904.

[/quote]

Just because it was proposed doesn’t mean he found a way to do it.[/quote]

1894: Nikola Tesla wirelessly lights up single-terminal incandescent lamps at the 35 South Fifth Avenue laboratory, and later at the 46 E. Houston Street laboratory in New York City by means of “electrodynamic induction,” i.e., wireless resonant inductive coupling.[4][5][6]

???

Read full topic

item.title: Wireless electricity
item.dc:creator: @Fat_Cookies Fat Cookies
item.description:
@Fat_Cookies wrote:

This fails hard because unlike mobile phone signals, the electric magnetic fields produced by that transmitter has to have some sort of long term effect on your health. iirc they could fuck up hard-drives as well :S

Nobody made a topic about because as lawl, this is really old. Just like most technology: we know about something now but it becomes commercially available in the next decade or two.

Read full topic
